body:
I see, so this is specific to the case where the sparse matrix is **very** sparse, and will mostly be employed in `LookupTable`/`Embedding` gradient computations, right?

I was initially confused because I thought you would expose it in the same level as the dense operations (for example by overloading the `@` operator or inside `addmm`), but with a special case when one of the inputs is sparse.

But the real reason I was confused was that I was mixing in my mind the sparse gemm and the sparse addition use cases. :-)

I was thinking about the weight updates inside the optimizer (which is an addition, and not multiplication). In such a context, it might be good to have an overload to check for sparse addition [inside the standard `add` function](https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch/blob/master/torch/optim/sgd.py#L32), as such a pattern would happen with every optimizer whenever we have sparse gradients.
